qns.entangled.controller module¶

class qns.entangled.controller.ControllerEvent(protocol, init_time: Optional[float] = None)¶

Bases: qns.schedular.event.Event

This event will call ControllerProtocol's run function for centralized decision.

Parameters

  • protocol -- the ControllerProtocol

  • init_time -- the event's generation time in second

run(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator)¶

It is the real event's handle functions. run should be overrided.

Parameters

simulator -- the simulator.

class qns.entangled.controller.ControllerProtocol(entity: qns.entangled.controller.QuantumController, period=0.5, delay=0, distillation_schema=[], distillation_threshold=0.8, swapping_schema={}, swapping_possible=1)¶

Bases: qns.schedular.protocol.Protocol

This protocol is used as a simple controller application. It will first perfrom distillation on those entanglements that satisfies distillation_schema. Then, it will perfrom swapping on those who satisfies swapping_schema.

Parameters

  • entity -- the QuantumController

  • period -- the period time that the controller makes a decision

  • delay -- the delay time it used to make a decision

  • distillation_schema -- the distillation schema is a list of (u,v), where entanglements between (u,v) will check distillation

  • distillation_threshold -- if an entanglement's fidelity is lower than distillation_threshold, it will be used in distillation

  • swapping_schema -- the swapping schema is a set of {swapping_node: (start_nodes, end_nodes)}, where start_nodes and end_nodes is a list of quantum nodes.

  • swapping_possible -- the success possibility of swapping.

An example of distillation_schema is:

distillation_schema = [(n1, n2), (n1, n3), (n1, n4), 
    (n2, n3), (n2, n4), (n3, n4)]

An example of swapping_schema is:

swapping_schema = { 
    n2: ([n1], [n3]), 
    n3: ([n1], [n4])
}
handle(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator, msg: object, source=None, event: Optional[qns.schedular.event.Event] = None)¶

handle is one of the callback functions that can be used to handle the triggered event.

Parameters

  • simulator -- the simulator

  • msg -- anything, can be considered as the event's parameters

  • source -- the entity that generated the event

  • event -- the event

install(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator)¶

Insert ControllerEvent into simulator. Those events will be called periodly.

Parameters

simulator -- the simulator

run(simulator)¶

The real decision function. Those entangled qubits will be check for distillation frist and than swapping. Then, NodeDistillationEvent and NodeSwappingEvent will be generate to process swapping or distillation.

Parameters

simulator -- the simulator

class qns.entangled.controller.QuantumController(nodes=[], links=[], name=None)¶

Bases: qns.topo.basic.Node

This is a controller in quantum network. It could be an SDN controller. It is used to arrange swapping and distillation.

Parameters

  • nodes -- the list of QuantumNode that it controlled.

  • links -- the list of QuantumChannel that it controlled.

  • name -- its name

qns.entangled.entanglement module¶

class qns.entangled.entanglement.Entanglement(nodes, birth_time_slice: int, fidelity: int = 1, life_func=None, name=None)¶

Bases: object

This class represents a Bell State Entangled qubits.

Parameters

  • nodes -- two QuantumNode that share this entangled qubit.

  • birth_time_slice -- its birthday

  • fidelity -- its fidelity

  • life_func -- a function that decide whether it is decohered. If it is None, the entanglement will be immortal.

  • name -- its name

is_alive()¶

Check whether it is still alive

Returns bool

is alive or not

qns.entangled.link module¶

class qns.entangled.link.GenerationProtocal(entity, possible=1, rate=10, delay=0.02, fidelity=1, allocate_step=1, under_controlled=False)¶

Bases: qns.schedular.protocol.Protocol

This is the entanglement generation protocol for QuantumChannel. This protocol will generate new entanglements continuously.

There will be a great overhead if every GenerationEvent is produced before the simulator runs. Setting an appropriate allocate_step can effectively reduce the initialization time.

Parameters

  • entity -- a QuantumChannel.

  • possible -- the success possibility of generate an entanglement.

  • rate -- generate rate new entanglements per second.

  • delay -- the delay time for each generation.

  • fidelity -- the initial fidelity of generated entanglement.

  • allocate_step -- the step time to schedule the next several GenerationEvent. The default value is 1 second.

  • under_controlled -- whether the EPR will generate spontaneously. If under_controlled is False, it will generate entanglements when generation is called.

allocate(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator)¶

The functions is called by GenerationAllocateEvent It will arrange the GenerationEvent in the following allocate_step second.

Parameters

simulator -- the simulator

generation(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator)¶

This is the real generation function, it generat new entanglement e and use GenerationEntanglementAfterEvent event to notify nodes to store new entanglemnt.

Parameters

simulator -- the simulator

qns.entangled.node module¶

class qns.entangled.node.KeepUseSoonProtocol(entity, dest, fidelity=0)¶

Bases: object

This protocol should be loaded on QuantumNode. It is used to simulate upper-level applications using entanglement. It keeps checking whether there is any distributed target entanglement and its fidelity is larger than fidelity. If so, it will move that entnaglement into used_e and increase the counter used.

Parameters

  • entity -- a QuantumNode

  • dest -- the target destination. The target entanglement should be shared between self and dest

  • fidelity -- the low bound of fidelity. The entanglement's fidelity must be larger than fidelity

Variables

  • used -- the counter of used entanglements.

  • used_e -- the storaged for used entanglements.

handle(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator, msg: object, source=None, event=None)¶

This funcion is called every time when a new entanglement is restored in the registers.

Parameters

  • msg -- anything, can be considered as the event's parameters

  • source -- the entity that generated the event

  • event -- the event

class qns.entangled.node.QuantumNodeDistillationProtocol(entity: qns.entangled.node.QuantumNode, threshold: float = 0, delay: float = 0, lazy_run_step=None, under_controlled=False)¶

Bases: qns.schedular.protocol.Protocol

This is the distillation protocol for QuantumNode.

If under_controlled is True, it will check if there are two entanglements in allow_distillation that their fidelity is lower than threshold. If so, it will perfrom distillation spontaneously.

If under_controlled is False, the swapping will not happen independently. In this case, NodeDistillationEvent should be generate to trigger entanglement swapping.

Parameters

  • entity -- a QuantumNode

  • threshold -- the lower bound of entanglement's fidelity. It an entanglement's fidelity is lower than threshold, it should be distillated.

  • delay -- the delay time of swapping operation

  • lazy_run_step -- The period that the node should check the fidelity states. It is a time in second. If lazy_run_step is None, periodly check will not happen. In this case, the handle will be triggled when a new entanglement is restored in the registers.

  • under_controlled (bool) -- Whether this node's swapping is under controlled.

Variables

allow_distillations -- a list of nodes. Entanglement between entity and node in allow_distillation will be checked.

distillation(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator, e1, e2)¶

The real distillation function. It will use e1 and e2 to generate a new entanglement with higher fidelity.

Default success possibility is f_min**2 + (1-f_min)**2 and defaulty new fidelity is f_min**2 / (f_min**2 + (1-f_min)**2), where f_min = min(e1.fidelity, e2.fidelity)

Parameters

  • simulator -- the simulator

  • e1 (Entanglement) -- a material entanglement

  • e2 (Entanglement) -- a material entanglement

handle(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator, msg: object, source=None, event: Optional[qns.schedular.event.Event] = None)¶

This funcion is called every time when a new entanglement is restored in the registers.

Parameters

  • simulator -- the simulator

  • msg -- anything, can be considered as the event's parameters

  • source -- the entity that generated the event

  • event -- the event

class qns.entangled.node.QuantumNodeSwappingProtocol(entity, possible=1, delay=0, fidelity_func=None, under_controlled=False)¶

Bases: qns.schedular.protocol.Protocol

This is the swapping protocol for QuantumNode .

If under_controlled is True, it will check if there are two entanglements that fits swapping_schema. If so, it will perfrom swapping spontaneously.

If under_controlled is False, the swapping will not happen independently. In this case, NodeSwappingEvent should be generate to trigger entanglement swapping.

Parameters

  • entity -- a QuantumNode

  • possible -- the success rate of swapping

  • delay -- the delay time of swapping operation

  • fidelity_func -- a fidelity function. if it is None , the default function will be used. In this case, the new generated entanglement's fidelity is f1 * f2.

  • under_controlled (bool) -- Whether this node's swapping is under controlled.

Variables

swapping_schema -- It is the swapping schema in the following format: [left_hand_nodes,right_hand_nodes], where both left_hand_nodes and right_hand_nodes is a list of quantum nodes.

fidelity(e1, e2)¶
handle(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator, msg: object, source=None, event: Optional[qns.schedular.event.Event] = None)¶

This funcion is called every time when a new entanglement is restored in the registers.

  • msg -- anything, can be considered as the event's parameters

  • source -- the entity that generated the event

swapping(simulator: qns.schedular.simulator.Simulator, e1: qns.entangled.entanglement.Entanglement, e2: qns.entangled.entanglement.Entanglement)¶

The real swapping function. It will aggreate e1 and e2 to distribute a new entanglement.

Parameters

  • e1 (Entanglement) -- a material entanglement

  • e2 (Entanglement) -- a material entanglement
